July 2019 
 
 
 
 
Supporting Improved Health Outcomes in Asia and 
the Pacific

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support efforts of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) developing member countries (DMCs) to address remaining poverty 
and inequality by improving health outcomes of DMCs through (i) identification and preparation 
of concept notes for health projects, (ii) health sector assessments and analyses to identify best 
practices and implementation bottlenecks, and (iii) development of health sector capacity in DMCs. 
 
2.  The TA1 is included in the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department’s 
2019 results-based work plan and will provide needed support for the implementation of ADB’s 
Strategy 2030,2 particularly operational priority 1 to address remaining poverty and reduce 
inequalities, and operational priority 7 to promote regional cooperation and integration. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Many countries in Asia and the Pacific have made great strides in poverty reduction and 
economic growth. However, there are unfinished development agendas, including the need to 
improve health outcomes and to attain and sustain universal health coverage (UHC). Issues that 
must be addressed include (i) epidemiological and demographic transitions such as increasing 
noncommunicable  diseases,  aging,  and  rapid  population  growth  in  many  countries;  (ii) 
urbanization and subsequent growth of the urban poor; (iii) migration and displacement resulting 
in increased pressure on health and other social services; (iv) threats of disease outbreak, which 
pose constant challenges to health systems; (v) the adaptation of health systems to be sensitive 
and responsive to the needs of women across the whole life cycle; (vi) the use of e-health to 
maximize health system efficiency;3 and (vii) strengthening of local governments’ role in delivering 
health care in decentralized settings. Emerging trends, such as technological advancements, 
increased emphasis on multisector collaboration, rising demand for quality health care as nations 
get richer, and economies graduating from donor support, present further opportunities and 
challenges in achieving UHC. 
 
4.  Strategy 2030 sets the course for ADB to respond more effectively to these changing 
needs,  emerging  opportunities,  and  challenges.  ADB  will  promote  the  use  of  innovative 
technologies, particularly scalable e-health solutions in the health sector, by delivering integrated 
strategies and bringing in expertise across a range of sectors and themes through a mix of public 
and private sector operations. ADB will continue to partner with DMCs as they pursue UHC by 
scaling up its assistance in the design and implementation of interventions to address three core 
aspects of achieving UHC: (i) expanding health coverage, (ii) improving quality of care, and (iii) 
financial protection for all. ADB will support efforts to address emerging regional challenges to 
achieving UHC, which include managing the growing burden of noncommunicable diseases, 
responding  to  the  need  for  elderly  care  in  a  cost-effective  and  sustainable  manner,  and 
strengthening regional health security.4 These contributions are expected to ultimately improve 
health outcomes for all people, independent of their ability to pay. 
                                                
1  This TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 June 2019. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  E-health refers to a range of strategies for integrating innovative technologies to improve health systems, including 
supporting the development of new strategies and investment cases, and enabling the interoperability of existing 
health information systems within and between countries. 
4  Regional health security refers to activities required to minimize vulnerability to acute public health events that        
    endanger the collective health of populations living across geographical regions and international boundaries.

2 
 
5.  This support for DMCs will build on the increasing number of recently committed, approved, 
and proposed sovereign and nonsovereign health projects. Gains made under the Operational 
Plan for Health 2015–20205 have resulted in increased focus on health, reflected by the rising 
number of health sector projects approved and committed by ADB’s operations departments. 
Current  and  planned  operational  priorities  include  (i)  the  implementation  of  the  Asian 
Development Fund 12 set-aside for regional health security; (ii) the expansion of ADB’s presence 
in e-health; (iii) the engagement of health sector-related policy dialogue with at least 20 DMCs; 
(iv) the convening of knowledge events on emerging issues at the national, regional, and global 
levels; and (v) the production and compilation of knowledge products, which capture knowledge 
generated since the approval of the Operational Plan for Health 2015–2020 in March 2015. 
 
6.  Despite progress in several health-specific areas, ADB needs to continue and deepen its 
support to DMCs to develop and implement UHC strategies, plans, policies, or programs. Timely 
policy dialogue and enhanced capacities by ADB’s operations departments and resident missions 
will support the exploration, development, and preparation of sovereign and nonsovereign health 
projects with DMCs. 
 
7.  The  TA  provides  the  needed  knowledge  and  technical  inputs  that  will  support  the 
prioritization, development, and institutionalization of innovations and best practices to accelerate 
the achievement of UHC. The synthesis of common themes and lessons learned across country-
level and regional reviews and the compilation of a network of professionals with health expertise 
in the Asia and Pacific region will strengthen ADB’s ability to respond to regional health issues. It 
will build on previous work generated by the Regional Malaria and Other Communicable Disease 
Threats Trust Fund (RMTF) and the regional TA for Universal Health Coverage for Inclusive 
Growth: Supporting the Implementation of the Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020. RMTF 
contributed to the reduction of risk from drug-resistant malaria and other communicable disease 
threats in the Asia and Pacific region and helped mobilized increased domestic funding for malaria 
elimination in the Greater Mekong subregion with the funding tripling from $90 million in 2013 to 
more than $300 million in 2018.6  The regional UHC for Inclusive Growth TA has supported the 
development of knowledge products including  health financing and service delivery diagnostics 
needed to inform country-led UHC policies and reforms. Priority areas will continue to be 
supported, including regional health security, national health insurance and other health financing 
systems, promotion of e-health, contracting of health care providers, demand analysis of hospitals, 
noncommunicable  diseases,  and  other  health  system  issues.  The  TA  will  facilitate  ADB’s 
expanded presence in the health sector in Asia and the Pacific, ultimately allowing ADB to be 
better positioned to help DMCs fill investment gaps to achieve UHC in a manner that is both timely 
and responsive to their needs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: access to needed quality health services 
improved in Asia and the Pacific DMCs (footnote 2). The TA will have the following outcome: 
                                                
5  ADB. 2015. Health in Asia and the Pacific: A Focused Approach to Address the Health Needs of ADB Development 
Member Countries. Manila. 
6  ADB.  2018. Completion Report: Results for Malaria Elimination and Control of Communicable Disease Threats in  
   Asia and the Pacific. Manila

3 
capacity of selected DMCs to implement best practices and innovative solutions in health systems 
enhanced.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Development of sovereign and nonsovereign health projects supported. 
The TA will provide consultant support to ADB’s operations departments, resident missions, and 
country offices to help with (i) the preparation of health sector assessments that will inform 
discussions  about  country  programming  and  country  partnership  strategies;  and  (ii)  the 
development of sovereign and nonsovereign health projects in at least five DMCs, which may 
include Bangladesh, the People’s Republic of China, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Solomon Islands, 
Tonga, and Uzbekistan. However, additional DMCs may be supported based on consultations 
with ADB’s operations departments. Based on DMC baseline progress toward UHC and stated 
priorities, the TA could support the development and implementation of UHC strategies, plans, 
policies,  or  programs  that  incorporate  TA-identified  UHC-related  best  practices,  innovative 
technologies (particularly e-health technologies), and/or quality infrastructure. 
 
10.  Output 2: Technical guidance on universal health coverage best practices and 
innovative technologies in developing member countries provided. In close coordination 
with ADB’s operations departments, the TA will support the review of country-level health systems 
and health outcomes in at least five DMCs enumerated in output 1. Building on these reviews, a 
regional stocktaking exercise will be undertaken to identify gender-sensitive best practices and 
innovative technologies to achieve UHC and address health system challenges in Asia and the 
Pacific, while also considering the role of local governments in multilevel governance settings for 
health. The TA will synthesize lessons learned from country-level health reviews and will prepare 
a set of technical guidance materials and a region-wide analytical report that will inform DMCs on 
incorporating and scaling up innovative technologies in national health plans, policies, and 
programs to achieve UHC. Regular consultations with the operations department health staff will 
also be held to gather intelligence on the health sector needs expressed by governments, and 
also to regularly test the assumptions of the innovative technologies. In addition, non-health sector 
interventions,  which  have  been  sustainably  leveraged  to  improve  health  outcomes,  will  be 
identified,  their  health  benefits  will  be  quantified,  and  future  opportunities  for  multisector 
engagement will be promoted. 
 
11.  Output 3: Knowledge on universal health coverage best practices for improved 
health outcomes expanded. This TA will support a series of knowledge events that will include 
online information exchange, the development of a network of consultants that countries and ADB 
officials can call upon to support health-related activities, and linkages with academic institutions 
to support operational research. These consultants will be organized by expertise and geographic 
region to provide timely, locally relevant expert support to DMCs in the design and implementation 
of UHC programs. Knowledge events will be held for DMC officials, development partners, and 
other stakeholders to disseminate and validate the review findings; share technical guidance 
materials; and identify priority health-related targets, capacity needs, and follow-up actions. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
                                                
7  The design and monitoring framework is available in Appendix 1.

4 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA and will be the executing agency. In close coordination with 
ADB’s operations departments, the Health Sector Group Secretariat (HSGS), under the Sector 
Advisory Service Cluster of ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, 
will  implement  the  TA  and  be  accountable  for  the  outputs.  The  HSGS  will  carry  out  TA 
administration, supervision, implementation oversight, and communication with consultants and 
stakeholders in close collaboration with the operations departments and other sector and thematic 
groups.  In  particular,  the  HSGS  will  work  closely  with  ADB’s  regional  departments  in  the 
recruitment and management of national consultants. The HSGS will coordinate with ADB’s 
operations departments, resident missions, Private Sector Operations Department, and Office of 
Public–Private Partnership on the use of the available TA resources. 
 
14.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  July 2019–December 2022 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agency  Health Sector Group Secretariat under the Sector Advisory Service 
Cluster, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, 
ADB 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB

Disbursement  The technical assistance resources will be disbursed following 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank. 
Source: ADB. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants using lump-sum or output-based 
contracts following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated  project  administration  instructions  and/or  staff  instructions.  Individual  national 
consultants who are technical experts in priority areas (e.g., e-health, nutrition, and health 
financing) with intimate familiarity with their respective country context will conduct country-level 
health system analyses. They will work with three international consultants, each covering a 
different area of expertise: (i) health economics, (ii) health systems and e-health, and (iii) technical 
writing.8 The  consultants  will  document  best  practices,  stocktaking,  lessons  learned,  and 
guidance for implementing health projects to work toward achieving UHC across the region. The 
international consultant on health economics and the international consultant on health systems 
and e-health will be contracted for 16 person months each, while the international consultant on 
technical writing will be contracted for 4 person months. Each of the five national consultants will 
be engaged for 18 person months each. There will be total of 36 person months of international 
consultant inputs and 90 person months of national consultant inputs. After the completion of the 
knowledge products, DMC officials and other stakeholders will be invited to participate in a series 
of  capacity  building  events,  which  will  promote  the  sharing  of  lessons  learned  and  new 
opportunities while also building capacity to design and implement effective programs across the 
region. 
                                                
8  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Improved Health Outcomes in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Development of sovereign and nonsovereign health projects supported 
1.1 Consult with operations departments in engaging with DMCs (starting Q3 2019) 
1.2 Engage national consultants for DMC-level stocktaking to support the adoption of the technical 
guidance by DMC-level stocktaking consultants as part of their support and advice to DMCs (starting 
Q4 2019)

Appendix 1  7 
1.3 Approve at least five DMCs with approved concept notes for health projects incorporating best 
practices and innovative technologies (completed by Q2 2022) 
 
2.  Technical guidance on UHC best practices and innovative technologies in DMCs provided 
2.1 Engage international and national consultants to undertake region-wide analysis and DMC-level 
stocktaking (starting Q4 2019) 
2.2 Conduct analysis and synthesis of country-level stocktaking reports (starting Q4 2019) 
2.3 Engage international consultants to prepare technical guidance materials (starting by Q4 2019) 
2.4 Disseminate regional review and stocktaking reports (starting Q1 2020) 
2.5 Draft the regional review of health outcomes and stocktaking of innovative solutions based on 
country-level reports (completed by Q3 2020) 
2.6 Draft the technical guidance materials (starting Q4 2019 and completed by Q4 2020) 
 
3.  Knowledge on UHC best practices for improved health outcomes expanded 
3.1 Develop a network of health experts and disseminate to regional offices (starting Q4 2019, 
completed by Q2 2022). 
3.2 Design a series of knowledge events on UHC best practices and designate team to implement                 
(completed by Q3 2020) 
3.3 Conduct a series of knowledge events on UHC best practices and lessons learned (completed by Q1 
2021)
